questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents to the hospital with complaints of fever, productive cough, and chest pain. Chest imaging reveals the presence of multiple cavitary lesions in the lung parenchyma. Microscopic examination of lung tissue obtained via biopsy demonstrates numerous neutrophils and macrophages surrounding fungal hyphae. Which of the following phenomena is most likely associated with the formation of these cavitary lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Impaired phagocytosis

Explanation:

A 45-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with fever, productive cough, and chest pain, and chest imaging shows multiple cavitary lesions in the lungs; biopsy reveals fungal hyphae surrounded by neutrophils and macrophages, with the formation of these cavities most likely linked to impaired phagocytosis.

  • In cases of severe infection or in the presence of large pathogen loads, the process of phagocytosis may become ineffective, resulting in incomplete or impaired phagocytosis which is known as ‘Frustrated Phagocytosis.’

  • Frustrated fibrofibrosis:

    • Macrophages cannot engulf large fungal hyphae

    • Leads to the release of lysosomal enzymes

    • Causes tissue necrosis and cavity formation

  • Seen in poorly controlled diabetics with fungal infections

  • Microscopy: Fungal hyphae surrounded by neutrophils and macrophages

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents with recurrent bacterial infections, including otitis media and pneumonia. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly reduced levels of all immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM). Flow cytometry analysis shows a complete absence of mature B cells in peripheral blood. Which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) BTK gene

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation suggests X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) also known as Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia, an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by a complete absence or markedly reduced number of mature B cells in peripheral blood due to mutations in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene located on the X chromosome.

  • B cells are absent or markedly decreased in circulation, but the pre-B cell level is normal in the bone marrow.
  • XLA is characterized by markedly reduced levels of all immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM), leading to hypogammaglobulinemia and defective Opsonization (due to ↓IgG).
  • It typically presents in infancy with recurrent bacterial infections, particularly affecting the respiratory tract, ears, and sinuses.
  • Replacement therapy with immunoglobulins (IVIG) is the mainstay of treatment.

 

Gene mutation

Diseases

Findings

BTK gene

X-linked agammaglobulinemia or

Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia

Hypogammaglobulinemia

(↓IgG, IgA, and IgM).

LYST gene

(Option B)

Chediak-Higashi syndrome

Giant granules in neutrophils

are visible in peripheral blood

smears.

.

WASP gene

(Option C)


 

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

Triad of thrombocytopenia,

eczema, and recurrent

infections

ADA gene

(Option D)

Severe Combined

Immunodeficiency

Profound lymphopenia

(primarily T-cells) and absent or

reduced ADA enzyme activity.

questions.text: Which of the following defects is most likely associated with Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency Type 1 (LAD)-1?

choices.text: Defective synthesis of Sialyl Lewis X modified glycoprotein

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Defective synthesis of β2 integrin

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency Type 1 (LAD-1), which is characterized by defective synthesis of the β2 chain of CD11/CD18 integrins (β2 integrin), resulting in defective leukocyte adhesion to endothelium.

  • Leukocyte Adhesion deficiencies (LAD) are rare autosomal recessive disorders

LAD-1

LAD-2

LAD-3

Defective synthesis of β2 chain of CD11/CD18 integrins (β2 integrin).

(Option A)

Defective synthesis of sialyl-Lewis X modified glycoprotein, a ligand for E- and P-selectins.

(Option B)

Mutations in the FERMT3 genes.

(Option C)

Clinical manifestations include delayed separation of the umbilical cord stump in newborns, and recurrent bacterial infections.

Clinically, LAD 2 patients may exhibit a Bombay Blood group phenotype.

Clinical presentation is similar to LAD-1, along with bleeding disorders due to platelet dysfunction.

 

 

Myeloperoxidase deficiency (Option D) is a rare inherited autosomal recessive disorder in which neutrophils lack functional MPO enzymes, impairing their ability to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) essential for microbial killing. Due to reduced microbicidal activity, these patients are susceptible to recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, especially in mucosal tissues (invasive candida infection).

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by recurrent catalase positive bacterial, and fungal infections, defective nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test results, and deficient reactive oxygen species production by phagocytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation, with recurrent catalase-positive bacterial and fungal infections, negative nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test results, and deficient reactive oxygen species production by phagocytes, is due to defective NADPH Oxidase, suggesting Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

  • It can be X-linked recessive (75% cases) or autosomal recessive (25% cases).
  • diagnosis: 
    • Nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) is a screening test commonly used to assess the respiratory burst activity of phagocytes. In CGD, phagocytes fail to reduce NBT to its insoluble form, resulting in a negative NBT test.
    • Dihydrorhodamine test (DHR) is the confirmatory test for CGD done by flow cytometry.


Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (Option A): Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD) is a group of disorders characterized by defects in leukocyte adhesion or migration, leading to impaired immune responses. It is of 3 types: 

  • LAD I: Defect in β2 integrin
  • LAD II: Deficiency of sialyl-Lewis X
  • LAD III: Mutation in the FERMT3 gene

Hyper-IgM Syndrome (Option B) is a group of primary immunodeficiency disorders marked by elevated IgM levels and decreased levels of other immunoglobulin isotypes, resulting from defects in either the CD40 ligand and the CD40 receptor.

X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (Option C), also known as Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia or Bruton's disease, is caused by mutations in the BTK gene and primarily affecting boys, is characterized by a lack of mature B cells and impaired immunoglobulin production, resulting in recurrent bacterial infections​​​​​​.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal discomfort and bloating. Upon further evaluation, an abdominal ultrasound reveals a heterogeneous mass within the right ovary. Subsequent histopathological examination of the ovarian mass demonstrates the presence of entotic cells. Which of the following best describes the process observed in the histopathological findings?

choices.text: Phagocytosis of apoptotic cells by neighboring cells
Engulfment of live cells by neighboring cells
Fusion of lysosomes within a cell leading to autophagy
Exocytosis of cellular debris from a damaged cell

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Engulfment of live cells by neighbouring cells

Explanation:

A 30-year-old female presents with abdominal discomfort and bloating, and abdominal ultrasound reveals a heterogeneous mass in the right ovary; histopathological examination shows entotic cells, indicating the engulfment of live cells by neighboring cells.

  • Entosis is a phenomenon where live cells are engulfed and internalized by neighbouring cells, forming cell-in-cell structures.
  • It typically occurs in non-phagocytic cells and can be observed in various physiological and pathological contexts, including tumour microenvironments.
  • In the scenario described, the presence of entotic cells within the ovarian mass indicates that live cells are being engulfed by neighbouring cells within the ovary.

 


Phagocytosis of apoptotic cells by neighbouring cells (Option A): Phagocytosis involves the clearance of dead or apoptotic cells by neighbouring phagocytic cells such as macrophages. However, entosis involves the engulfment of live cells, not apoptotic cells.

Fusion of lysosomes within a cell leading to autophagy (Option C): Autophagy is a cellular process involved in the degradation and recycling of cellular components but no engulfment of neighboring cells.

Exocytosis of cellular debris from a damaged cell (Option D): Exocytosis is the process by which cells release molecules or cellular components into the extracellular space, and it does not involve the engulfment of neighboring cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Emperipolesis and Phagocytosis?

choices.text: Emperipolesis involves engulfment by any cell depending on disease; Phagocytosis involves engulfment by macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells.
Emperipolesis doesn’t involve the killing of the cell; phagocytosis results in the degradation of engulfed cells.
Emperipolesis maintains internalized cell membrane integrity; Phagocytosis involves the fusion of engulfed material with lysosomes.
Emperipolesis is physiological; phagocytosis is pathological.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Emperipolesis is physiological; phagocytosis is pathological.

Explanation:

Emperipolesis is seen in pathological conditions where phagocytosis is a physiological response.

Emperipolesis

Phagocytosis

Emperipolesis is a cellular phenomenon characterized by the internalization of one cell within another without causing cell death.

Phagocytosis is a cellular process by which certain specialized cells engulf and digest foreign particles, pathogens, dead cells, and cellular debris.

The large cell dependant on organ/ disease (Option A ruled out)

Engulfing cells can be macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells. (Option A ruled out)

No killing of the internalized cell. The engulfed cell often remains viable within the host cell. (Option B ruled out)

Typically digest and degrade the engulfed material such as bacteria or cellular debris. (Option B ruled out)

The engulfed cell maintains its own membrane integrity. (Option C ruled out)

The engulfed material typically fuses with lysosomes for digestion. (Option C ruled out)

It is seen in pathological conditions such as autoimmune diseases, lymphoproliferative disorders, or histiocytic disorders. (Option D)

It is a physiological process essential for tissue homeostasis and immune defence. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male complains of painless bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy for the past six months. Biopsy of a lymph node reveals sheets of large histiocytes with emperipolesis, surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rosai-Dorfman disease

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings suggest Rosai-Dorfman disease which typically presents with painless bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and is characterized by the presence of large histiocytes with emperipolesis, where intact lymphocytes are seen within the cytoplasm of histiocytes.

Emperipolesis is the phenomenon of one cell residing within another cell, usually a macrophage, without causing death to the cell.

  • The internalized cell is enclosed within the cytoplasmic vacuole of the host cell without fusion of their membranes.
  • This phenomenon is seen in conditions like (Mnemonic - MARC):
    • Myelodysplastic Syndrome/Myeloproliferative Neoplasm (MDS/MPN)
    • Autoimmune Hepatitis (Lymphocytes and plasma cells may be seen within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes).
    • Rosai-Dorfman disease
    • Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)

 

Hodgkin’s lymphoma (Option A) is identified by Reed-Sternberg cells (Owl eye appearance), which are large, multinucleated cells with prominent nucleoli but not associated with emperipolesis.

Sarcoidosis (Option B) is characterized by non-caseating granulomas.

Infectious mononucleosis (Option C), caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), can present with cervical lymphadenopathy, but it typically involves lymphoid hyperplasia with reactive lymphocytes but doesn’t show large histiocytes with emperipolesis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) is incorrect?

choices.text: NETs are formed in response to infectious pathogens and inflammatory mediators.
NETs consist of nuclear chromatin and granule proteins like antimicrobial peptides and enzymes.
NET formation is initiated by the release of histones from activated neutrophils.
NETs directly phagocytose the invading pathogens.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) NETs directly phagocytose the invading pathogens.

Explanation:

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are extracellular fibrillar structures that localize antimicrobial substances at infection sites and trap microbes, helping to prevent their spread by directly targeting invading pathogens.

  • NETs do not directly phagocytose or engulf the invading pathogens. Instead, they trap pathogens within their structure, immobilizing them and allowing other immune cells, such as macrophages, to recognize and eliminate them. (Option D)
  • They are produced by neutrophils in response to infectious pathogens (mainly bacteria and fungi) and inflammatory mediators (e.g., chemokines, cytokines, complement proteins, and ROS). (Option A ruled out)
  • NET formation starts with ROS-dependent activation of an arginine deaminase that converts arginine to citrulline, leading to chromatin decondensation.
  • NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin and various granule proteins, including antimicrobial peptides and enzymes that help to neutralize and kill pathogens trapped within the NETs. (Option B ruled out)
  • Activated neutrophils release histones into the extracellular space, which helps to unwind and release the DNA, allowing it to combine with granule proteins and form the characteristic web-like structure of NETs. (Option C ruled out)
  • They have been detected in conditions like sepsis, emphasizing their importance in immune protection.
  • The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus, in which individuals react against their own DNA and nucleoproteins.

 

 

                                        A neutrophil granulocyte (yellow) has ejected a NET (green) to capture bacteria (purple). A red blood cell (orange) is also trapped in the NET.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with recurrent bacterial infections. Laboratory tests reveal reduced opsonization activity in his serum. Which of the following processes is primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Microbial engulfment

Explanation:

A 40-year-old male presents with recurrent bacterial infections, and laboratory tests show decreased opsonization activity in his serum, indicating that the primary process affected is microbial engulfment.

  • Microbial engulfment refers to the process by which phagocytes engulf and internalize pathogens for destruction.
  • Opsonization plays a critical role in this process by coating pathogens with opsonins that enhance phagocytosis.
  • Reduced opsonization activity in serum directly impacts microbial engulfment, as pathogens are less efficiently recognized and phagocytosed by immune cells.

Opsonins are substances that coat pathogens or foreign particles, making them more recognizable and easier for phagocytic cells to engulf.

  • They act as "handles" that bind to both the pathogen and the receptor on the phagocyte.

 

  • Opsonin is divided into 3 Categories:
    • IgG (Most important opsonin)
    • Complement proteins (C3b, C4b, C5b ): The most important complement opsonin C3b
    • Plasma Protein (E.g., Fibrinogen)

     Effect of reduced opsonization:

  • Phagocytes (macrophages/neutrophils) cannot efficiently engulf microbes

  • Leads to recurrent infections

 

Complement activation (Option A), Diapedesis (Option B), and Leukocyte rolling (Option D) are not affected by reduced opsonization.

questions.text: Which among the following is a cardinal sign of inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Redness

Explanation:

Among the given options, redness is one of the cardinal signs of inflammation. 

Cardinal signs of inflammation:

  • Redness (Rubor) is caused by increased blood flow to the affected area due to vasodilation of blood vessels.
  • Heat (Calor): The increased temperature at the site of inflammation due to vasodilation and increased blood flow.
  • Swelling (Tumor): Accumulation of fluid and inflammatory cells, leading to tissue swelling.
  • Pain (Dolor): Sensory nerve stimulation due to tissue damage, increased pressure from swelling, and release of inflammatory mediators.
  • Loss of Function (Functio Laesa): Impairment or loss of normal tissue function.
    • While the 1st four signs were given by Celsus, Functio Laesa was given by Sir Rudolf Virchow.

 

Prolonged fever, Tissue scarring and Abrasions (Option A,B and C) are not cardinal sign of inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following plays a crucial role in mediating firm adhesion of leukocytes during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) CD11a/CD18

Explanation:

CD11a/CD18 plays a crucial role in mediating firm adhesion of leukocytes during acute inflammation.

Adhesion types in inflammation:

  • Rolling & weak adhesion → mediated by selectins

  • Firm adhesion → mediated by integrins

    • β₁ integrin (VLA)

    • β₂ integrin (LFA-1/MAC-1 = CD11/CD18) → mediates firm adhesion (Option A)

 

​​​​​​​PECAM 1 (platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule 1), also known as CD31, plays a role in leukocyte transmigration across endothelial junctions. (Options B & C ruled out).

CD44 (Option D) is a cell surface glycoprotein that serves as a receptor for hyaluronic acid, a component of the extracellular matrix. It does not involve firm adhesion of transmigration of leukocytes.

questions.text: A patient presents with fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity. Which of the following  characteristics would be consistent with a diagnosis of exudate rather than a transudate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) High LDH

Explanation:

Of the options provided, elevated LDH is a distinguishing feature of an exudate.

Features

Transudate

Exudate

Mechanism

Ultrafiltrate of plasma due to increased hydrostatic pressure with normal vascular permeability (non-inflammatory process).

Inflammatory process with increased vascular permeability

Appearance

Clear, serous fluid

Cloudy/purulent/hemorrhagic

Specific gravity (Option D ruled out)

Low (<1.018)

High (>1.018)

Protein (Option B, C ruled out)

Low (<2g/dl), mainly albumin

High (>2g/dl)

Clot

Absent

Present (Due to high fibrinogen level)

Cell count

Low

High

Types of cells

Few lymphocytes and mesothelial cells

Neutrophils in acute and lymphocytes in chronic inflammation

Bacteria

Absent

Present

LDH (Option A)

Low

High

Seen in
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic Syndrome
  • Pyogenic infections
  • Malignancy
  • Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the hallmark event of acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased vascular permeability

Explanation:

Increased vascular permeability, particularly in postcapillary venules, is considered the primary hallmark event of acute inflammation. This process enables the passage of plasma proteins, fluids, and white blood cells from the bloodstream into the tissue.

Vascular Events of Acute Inflammation: 

  • Vasoconstriction: Due to reflex of the injury 
  • Vasodilation: Induced by mediators (histamine, serotonin) - an early event in acute inflammation. It leads to the widening of blood vessels, increased blood flow, and subsequent redness (erythema) and warmth at the site of inflammation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Increased vascular permeability - Hallmark (Option B)
  • Stasis (slowing blood flow): Characterized by sluggish blood flow and the accumulation of leukocytes along the vascular endothelium, it is a consequence of increased vascular permeability and contributes to the inflammatory process but is not the primary hallmark event. (Option C ruled out)

Leukocyte extravasation (Option D): Leukocyte extravasation, or the migration of white blood cells from the bloodstream to the tissue, is a crucial stage in the inflammatory process. However, it occurs after increased vascular permeability and is not the hallmark feature of acute inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms primarily contributed to the increased vascular permeability in this patient's with a right knee injury after fall from stairs?

choices.text: Contraction of endothelial cells resulting in the opening of interendothelial gaps

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Contraction of endothelial cells resulting in the opening of interendothelial gaps

Explanation:

Increased vascular permeability in this patient with a right knee injury from a fall is mainly caused by endothelial cell contraction, which creates interendothelial gaps.

  • The primary mechanism is the contraction of endothelial cells, leading to the opening of interendothelial gaps.
  • This is mediated by various inflammatory mediators released in response to tissue injury, including histamine, bradykinin, and leukotrienes.
  • Immediate transient response (occurs within minutes and lasts for a short duration)

Direct damage to endothelial cells (Option B), Neutrophil-mediated injury to the endothelium (Option C), and Proliferation of lymphatic vessels (Option D) do not mediate mechanical injury as given in the scenario.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset right lower abdominal pain, accompanied by nausea and fever. On examination, there is tenderness over McBurney's point, and rebound tenderness is noted. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis. Which type of inflammation is most likely to be associated with the following clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Purulent inflammation

Explanation:

The given clinical findings point towards the diagnosis of acute appendicitis, and purulent inflammation is likely to be associated with this condition.

  • Purulent inflammation is characterized by the production of pus, an exudate consisting of neutrophils, the liquefied debris of necrotic cells, and oedema fluid.
  • Abscesses are localized collections of pus caused by suppuration buried in tissue, organ, or confined space.

Serous inflammation (Option A): Accumulation of fluid in body cavities is called an effusion, which can occur due to increased vascular permeability or local irritation.

Fibrinous inflammation (Option B): Fibrinous inflammation involves the deposition of fibrin in the extracellular space due to increased vascular permeability.Histologically, fibrin appears as an eosinophilic meshwork of threads or an amorphous coagulum.

Ulcerative inflammation (Option D): Ulcerative inflammation involves local defects or excavations of an organ or tissue's surface caused by the shedding of inflamed necrotic tissue, which is common in mucosal surfaces, the skin, and subcutaneous tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following features is a  characteristic of acute inflammation?

choices.text: The predominance of lymphocytes in the inflammatory infiltrate
Accumulation of neutrophils at the site of injury

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Accumulation of neutrophils at the site of injury

Explanation:

Among the given options, the accumulation of neutrophils at the site of injury is a characteristic of Acute inflammation.

  • Acute inflammation → Predominated by neutrophils

    • Exception: Typhoid → lymphocyte predominance

Presence of granulomas (Option A) , Proliferation of fibroblasts and angiogenesis (Option B) , and The predominance of lymphocytes in the inflammatory infiltrate (Option C) are associated with chronic inflammation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of recent major surgery, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the lower extremities, and a family history of thrombotic events. Which of the following components constitute Virchow's triad, predisposing individuals to thrombosis?

choices.text: Endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and venous stasis
Endothelial dysfunction, leukocytosis, and platelet activation
Arterial dilation, decreased platelet count, and fibrinolysis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and venous stasis

Explanation:

Virchow's triad consists of three primary factors that contribute to thrombosis:

  • Endothelial injury- Triggers platelet adhesion and clot formation.
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow- Disrupts normal anticoagulant processes, promoting thrombosis.
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood- An increased tendency of blood to clot, often due to genetic or acquired conditions.
